story: Tory Nadine Dorries moans to BBCs Laura Kuenssberg for tweeting what an MP saidThe Tory Culture Secretary, whose Cabinet brief includes the BBC, later deleted the tweet as critics accused her of trying to police the Corporations outputNadine Dorries added another notch to her long list of criticisms of the BBC Image: Getty ImagesByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments The Tory Culture Secretary has been slammed for moaning at the BBC ’s political editor for tweeting what an MP said.Nadine Dorries, whose Cabinet brief includes the BBC, was accused of trying to police Laura Kuenssberg’s output in the now-deleted post. Ms Dorries, who has previously been highly critical of the BBC, took exception to an MP who told Ms Kuenssberg Boris Johnson “looked weak and sounded weak” at a meeting last night.The anonymous Tory MP claimed “authority is evaporating” during the gathering of the  Committee of back benchers. But Ms Dorries wrote: “Laura, I very much like and respect you, but we both know, that text is ridiculous.“Although nowhere near as ridiculous as the person - obviously totally desperate for your attention - who sent it”.  Askedshe sent the tweet publicly in error or why she deleted it, a source close to Ms Dorries declined to comment. Former London mayor candidate Siobhan Benita tweeted: “Nadine Dorries is not fit to be Culture Secretary.” Labour MP Karl Turner said: “Sec of State for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport publically [sic] tells off @bbclaurak for having the audacity to report Johnson’s terrible state today and then quickly deletes the tweet.”Twitter pundit James Felton added: “You know being Secretary of State for Culture, Media  Sport doesn’t mean you’re the boss of journalism right.”Ms Dorries later said she did not rebuke Laura Kuenssberg and never would. Shadow culture secretary Jo Stevens said: We have spent much of the past two weeks talking about standards in public office and on this side of the House we care deeply about the independence and the impartiality of the BBC. I know the Secretary of State also cares to the extent that she actually has the time to police the BBCaposs political editoraposs tweets and publicly rebuke her. Ms Dorries said: I did not rebuke Laura Kuenssberg, somebody who is maybe ... the best in the business actually, very professional, very polite tweet. The tweet was completely misinterpreted. I was not rebuking Laura Kuenssberg and never would.The Culture Secretary has a long history of eyebrow-raising tweets about the BBC and to journalists, among many other issues. In  she suggested ministers should withhold the licence fee payout at a round of negotiations, unless they did more to address discrimination.  In February  she wrote: “The BBC favour strident, very left wing, often hypocritical and frequently patronising views that turn people away.” In October  she wrote: “BBC needs to up its game in political presentation. Dull, boring, male and ageing wig wearing men losing the plot don’t cut it anymore.” On Nick Watt joining Newsnight, a role Andrew Neil hailed as “excellent”, she retorted: “Or in other words, the BBC recruits straight from , again.” On a Guido Fawkes story about a nurse interviewee worried about PPE being a left-wing activist, she replied: “Would the BBC ever put up a Conservatives activist  Don’t hold your breath…” She also threatened to nail a Sunday Mirror reporter’s testicles to the floor in  – for asking how her daughter could work as her secretary when she lived nearly  miles away. news uk-news bare-chested-england-football-yob-"This is the moment a bare-chested England football yob ran onto Riverside Stadium pitch during matchByJade McElweeKieren Williams:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA bare-chested football yob who ran onto the pitch after downing seven pints during an England match has been given a football banning order. Bailey Cassidy downed pints after pint at the Riverside Stadium before jumping over the barrier and running across the halfway line. He then removed his t-shirt and “waved it around his head”. The -year-old interrupted the European Championship warm-up game that saw the Three Lions take on Romania in June of this year. Cassidy has been a member of the England Supporters Association for  years, TeesideLive reports. He made a “fool of himself” during the -second hooliganism at the Middlesborough ground. Cassidy, from Suffolk, he was convicted at Teeside Magistrates’ Court for going into the playing area at a football match “without lawful authority or lawful excuse”.  He was brought back before the Middlesbrough court on Tuesday as police sought a football banning order. Prosecutor Rachel Butt stated the football banning order is “necessary to prevent violence and disorder”. The court was told how the offence was committed on June . Ms Butt told how a police officer who was deployed inside the ground at .pm for an incident during the first-half of the game.  Cassidy had climbed over the barriers and ran onto the pitch when the players were still playing. Cassidy ran away from police officers and was chased by a match steward. Ms Butt described how he then removed his t-shirt and waved it around his head as fans chanted in the background. When caught, Cassidy was taken to the North-west corner of the pitch where his eyes were glazed, he smelt of alcohol and his speech was slow.  Cassidy went on to give another man’s name when asked by police, and claimed he was from Manchester. He later confirmed his real name and was arrested. During interview, Cassidy admitted he had drank seven pints and admitted to his actions. When asked by officershis actions may have led to violence or disorder, he replied: Maybe more. Ms Butt applied for a minimum three year football banning order with a requirement that Cassidy does not enter the parish, city or town boundary eight hours before or after any England menaposs games.  Ross Tismond, mitigating, opposed the football banning order and stated there arenapost reasonable grounds for the ban. The court heard how Cassidy was on the pitch for  seconds and his actions were a one off event. Mr Tismond told how it was Cassidyaposs first opportunity to attend a football match with his father as he had been undergoing chemotherapy. However, Cassidy drank far too much. He was exceptionally drunk and made a fool of himself. Mr Tismond added that Cassidy was petried at the prospect of receiving a football banning order. District Judge Marie Mallon outlined that there are reasonable grounds to make the order as Cassidy went onto the playing area during play and crossed the halfway line. She added that the incident was severely exacerbated by the covid- pandemic as many players had formed bubbles and isolated in preparation for the game. The district judge made the football banning order for three years which will prevent Cassidy, of Roman Way, Heverhill, Suffolk, from causing disruption to England matches. On any day when the England senior menaposs national team are playing a fixture within England, Wales or Scotland the defendant must not enter the town, city or parish boundary wherein that fixture is being played, during the period eight hours before until eight hours after the scheduled kick off time. title: blind man gets sight back
story: Man blinded by tumour gets sight back and sees beautul girlfriend for first timeNathan Cummings,  became vision impaired after undergoing gruelling chemotherapy to battle a tumour and had never laid eyes on his girlfriend, but after le-changing surgery, he has finally been able to see her for the first timeNathan Cummings,  was told he had a cancerous brain tumour after he lost his balance at work Image: Blackpool Gazette   SWNSByNeil ShawShiler Mahmoudi:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA blind man who saw his girlfriendaposs face for the first time after surgery restored his eye-sight said: Sheaposs one of the most beautul people Iaposve ever met.Nathan Cummings, , was told he had cancer in  and met his girlfriend in earlier this year.He became signicantly vision impaired at the start of this year after going through gruelling “high-velocity” chemotherapy treatment.The -year-old started dating his girlfriend Samantha Maywood in June of this year after he met her on dating site E-harmony.He had never been able to see Samantha until he received le-changing treatment that enable to see again.Nathan from Blackpool was finally able to see his sweetheart earlier this week after undergoing two operations and laser eye surgeries, Wales Online reports.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter He described the moment as “The best feeling I have ever had.” He said: “When I first met her, I was blind. I said to her: “I’m going to look after you. You’re probably the most beautul person I have ever met. I still think that – even though I’ve got my eyesight back, I still think she’s one of the most beautul people I’ve ever met. She’s helped me out, even when I was blind. After losing his balance at work in , Nathan went to see a doctor to be checked out. It was found that the young man had a cancerous tumour in his brain the size of a ping-pong ball which required surgery. Despite the chances of a successful operation were slim, he was in surgery for eight hours which saved his le.However, things took a turn for a worse when he caught meningitis on his birthday later that year, and later on had sepsis on two separate occasions during chemotherapy. The aggressive nature of the chemotherapy caused him to lose his sight. Nathan said: “I got cataracts through the chemotherapy because it was high-velocity chemo. “I was blind for about a year.” During this time, he met his beau Samantha and the pair tried to maintain a normal dating le and even went to watch a movie in the cinema together. He said: “We went to see Fast and Furious . “I walked in, and it was pitch black, and I couldn’t see anything.  He added: “I didn’t really want to see it – I took her to say thanks for helping me.” During their initial dating le, Nathan said that Samantha “guided” him when they went out together. But his hopes of seeing his girlfriend of four months rose after he underwent a series of operations to try to restore his vision. He said: “I had two cataract surgeries, one where I didn’t get my sight back and another where I got my sight back, but it was still a bit blurry. “Then I had laser eye treatment a couple of weeks after, and then I could basically see.” Following the surgery last Thursday, Nathan described the point when he finally set eyes on his girlfriend as one of the best moments of his le.  He said: “That was the best feeling I have ever had, to be honest. Despite regaining his independence, Nathan said he won’t be able to change the structure of his dating le for some time to come. He said: I haven’t been in hospital for any time this year, except for at the beginning of the year. “But I’ve got a brain scan coming up in December, then I’ve got to go back for the results, so I don’t think I’ll be doing anything during then. title: cautious optimism christmas covid cases
story: Cautious optimism for Christmas but Covid cases likely to shoot up after, expert claimsThe lead scientist on the ZOE Covid study app, Professor Tim Spector, says hes "cautiously optimistic" that there wont be a surge in coronavirus cases over ChristmasProfessor Tim Spector says hes cautiously optimistic that Covid cases wont shoot up during Christmas Image: Getty ImagesByRyan FaheyReporterAine FoxNina Massey, PA:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA Covid expert says heaposs cautiously optimistic that Brits wonapost see a spike in cases over Christmas but fears infections will soar when schoolsafter the festive break. Lead ZOE Covid Study app scientist, Tim Spector, says itaposs clear kids and their school holidays have become a key role in the waves of infection. The Kingaposs College epidemiology professor repeated comments made last week that Brits should be ready for Covid to remain in our lives for the next five Christmases, and not just this one.His comments came as new data suggests recent coronavirus rates in England are similar to infections seen just after the peak of the second wave in January this year.From mid-October to early November, the prevalence was . per cent - the same as January - compared with . per cent in September.  According to the data, prevalence increased between rounds  and  of Imperial College Londonaposs React- study across most age groups and regions. During round , which ran from October  to November , there was a fall in prevalence from a peak at around October  to . School-aged children had the highest rates of infection with a prevalence of . per cent in those aged five to  and . per cent in those aged  to .  The data suggests all of the cases were the Delta iant or sub-lineages. The most prevalent was AY., which the scientists say is more likely to result in asymptomatic infection. Christl Donnelly, professor of statistical epidemiology at Imperial College London, said: It is absolutely the case thatpeople are waiting for symptoms to do a test and to therefore identy that they are infected, and therefore cut back their contacts, being asymptomatic may facilitate transmission for example.  It is asymptomatic transmission that really can make the dference between whataposs relatively easily containable and what needs vaccination. The AY.. mutation which officials are monitoring as a iant under investigation represented . per cent of infections. Researchers say the observational nature of survey data and the relatively small proportion of unvaccinated adults calls into question the comparability of vaccinated and unvaccinated groups.  However, they found that third vaccine doses for eligible adults and the vaccination of children aged  and over are associated with lower infection risk. The researchers say they should therefore remain a high priority - with possible extension to children aged five to  - and this should help reduce Covid transmission over the winter. The study has been released as a pre-print that has not been through peer review and is not published in a journal.  The latest data from the ZOE study led by Prof Spector suggested there are currently on average , new daily symptomatic cases of the virus in the UK, based on both PCR and rapid lateral flow test data from up to five days ago. This is a fall of  per cent from , new daily cases last week, researchers said. Prof Spector said: According to the ZOE data, the steep drop in cases over the last two weeks has now slowed but remains at very high rates, affecting one in  people. In terms of what it means for Christmas, Iaposm cautiously optimistic for the remainder of the year. Itaposs becoming clear that children and the school holidays play a key role in the waves of infection. I think itaposs safe to say that we can expect to see another rise in the new year after the holidays.  Thereaposs a long road ahead and I think weaposll be dealing with Covid for the next five years, so itaposs important we have a strategy that looks much further ahead and not just to save Christmas. He stressed the importance of healthy behaviours such as working more from home when possible and self-isolation with all symptoms, as well as wearing face coverings in high-risk areas. But Prof Spector said the most important thing is to get fully vaccinated, a term he said must be redefined to having three doses to protect us all from Delta and the inevitable new iants of Covid yet to come. The ZOE study showed that, in those who have had at least two doses of a vaccine, cases have levelled off and it is estimated there are currently , new daily symptomatic cases in the UK, down  per cent from , new daily cases last week. The number of daily new cases among people aged up to  - which had been falling - is showing signs of an uptick, researchers said. Cases in age groups between  to  have levelled off, while those among the over-s are now declining, they added. Care home boss, Nicola Richards, has founded the ‘ Support Social Care Heroes ’because she says “it’s time to look after these amazing workers.”They are hoping for donations from the nation so they can offer these “undervalued” and “exhausted” carers help including counselling, fitness, wellbeing coaching, menopause advice and nutrition programmes.Nicola, managing director of Palms Row Health Care and Chair of the Sheffield Care Association, said: “These carers need the same recognition as the NHS, the same discounts in stores, the same respect.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter They are the lowest paid workforce with one of the hardest jobs. Without them the community would break down. “Everybody at some point will probably need care workers to look after somebody, so we have to look after them because they have done an incredible job. “They have done it for years but the pandemic has highlighted how essential they are. They have become extended family to our residents during lockdown.  “Carers often work long, anti-social hours and they don’t often get the recognition and rewards they deserve. The situation was desperate before the pandemic but the last two years has seen them struggle like never before. “ She says SSCH, which is in the process of achieving charitable status, aims to “preserve, protect and improve the health and wellbeing of those providing social care”. There are . million people working in social care in the UK and this is expected to increase to . million by .  It is hoped that SSCH will receive signicant support following research which found that the overwhelming majority of the public feel that social care staff are undervaluedand underpaid . Nicola added: “The care sector loses its best people every week. “While the sector continues to fight for fair wages and conditions for carers, Support Social Care Heroes aims to fill a gap by improving the wellbeing of these vital workers and show them that they are valued. It’s time to care for our social care heroes.”  Nurse Laura Hibbard, Care Manager at Westbourne Care home in Sheffield, added: “The last  months have been so tough for everyone in the care sector. “Care home residents across the country have shown unimaginable resilience throughout the pandemic but the people who care for them are mentally, emotionally and physically exhausted. “No one becomes a carer for the money, we do it to improve the lives of vulnerable people. It can be a hugely rewarding experience but it can also be extremely dficult at times. Carers often feel forgotten so I think it’s wonderful that SSCH is being established to acknowledge the crucial role they play in our society.”  Nadra Ahmed OBE, Executive Chair of the National Care Association, commented: “Valuing our workforce for the professionalism they have shown through the past  months, and for many years before, is essential. “We must do everything we can to show them how much we care about them as they support those in our services. The passion with which Support Social Care Heroes is being launched as an innovative, led by providers, organisation demonstrates how invaluable our workforce is to us. “Being able to do something tangible for them when they need it most feels positive. Caring about those who care for others is the right thing to do.”Anyone who wishes to donate to or support Support Social Care Heroes can do so by visiting: www.ssch.info.Comment MORE ON NHSCharitiesCare homesCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Council slammed for leaving insensitive note at memorial bench for lost loved oneDominic Gillies spotted the "insensitive" note pinned to a memorial bench, which was adorned with floral tributes and other plants, while walking his dog in Southport, MerseysideThe memorial bench in Southport is adorned with a plaque, plants, other floral tributes and a note or two Image: Liverpool EchoByJon MacphersonRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsA local council has been slammed for leaving an insensitive note by a memorial bench.The bench in Southport, Merseyside, is adorned with floral tributes, other plants and a plaque to memorialise the lost loved one.But Sefton Council say the area is not suited as a grieving site and that decorations must be removed before December , Lancs Live reports.The notice read: Whilst we all share the sadness that comes when someone passes, it is not possible for us to allow memorials to perpetuate with signs, offerings and added flowers   baskets in the nature reserves. This can be damaging to the protected areas, and wildle, and can affect the enjoyment of other visitors, and is therefore not compatible with the location. Of course, our deepest sympathies are with those of you who have lost loved ones, and we are very sorrythis causes any offence, we do assure you that none is intended. The Council does have official memorial locations based on the cemeteries and crematoria and we believe that this is a much more suitable, sustainable and appropriate way forward for these types of memorial gestures. We are posting this notice to inform you that we will clear this location of the memorial offerings by Friday th December . Should you wish to remove them before this date, then of course you are very welcome to do so. Thank you for your understanding. Sefton Council. Dominic Gillies, who walks his dog past the bench and memorial everyday, called it insensitive in a tweet to the council.His tweet said: Hi @seftoncouncil shocked to see such an insensitive notice on my usual afternoon dog walk. Tell me this is a joke  None of this applies here. This bench and memorial for Mary damages nothing, harms no wildle, and only improves the area for visitors. Will you reconsider The -year-old sales manager told the ECHO : I walk past there with my dog every morning so itaposs nothing to do with me, I donapost know the person whose memorial it is but they have a nice picture of her up there. I often sit there with and have a rest whilst my dog runs around. I got there yesterday and wondered aposwhat the hell is that apos.Itaposs in between Royal Birkdale and Hillside golf courses. If you park up in the Royal Birkdale golf course car park there is a little walk through into the sand dunes and thereaposs a clearing there between the two golf courses. In a statement, a Sefton Council spokesperson said: “We intended no offence to be taken by the notice placed next to a memorial bench in the Birkdale Local Nature Reserve area.“We do all that we can to support those who wish to commission memorials in memory of loved ones, and our cemeteries and crematoriums provide permanent, lasting sites of remembrance. We do also have some locations available for memorial benches at parks, along our coast, and at green spaces across the Borough so that people have alternative places to spend time and reflect. “While these locations are beautul and extremely popular with our visitors, they are also environmentally sensitive. Our coastline is a designated Site of Special Scientic Interestso the Council has a duty to ensure that the area is effectively and appropriately managed to protect and conserve it. “We do ask people when they commission memorials benches, that no other items or tributes are attached to the seat other than the agreed plaque. The same goes for planting or planters around the bench. This is to ensure that no plastics or other harmful materials, or non-native species, can affect the erse flora and fauna that is protected by law at our coastal areas. “We make clear that we can remove any items of concern in order to protect these important habitats, and to ensure that members of the public can have safe and enjoyable access to these sites.” Comment MORE ON NHSCar parksSefton Council" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Doctor who spent months away from family on frontline battling pandemic dies of CovidSkilled surgeon and devoted family man, Dr Irfan Halim, has been remembered a medical powerhouse who had the skill of " men in one body" after his death from Covid on November Doctor Irfan Halim, a skilled surgeon at Swindon Hospital, has been remembered as a devoted husband and dad Image: www.walesonline Via FamilyByLaura ClementsRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA skilled surgeon who spent months away from his family saving lives during the height of the pandemic has died after a nine-week battle with Covid. Doctor Irfan Halim has been remembered as a devoted husband and dad to four children - all under the age of . He has been remembered as a medical powerhouse, like  men in one body, who treated more than , patients throughout his career. Devastated Salia Halim said her partner went to work at Swindon Hospital on September  and never came home, Wales Online reports.With a broken heart shattered in pieces beyond imagination, Saila Halim said: My beloved Irfan passed away on the Sunday, November  at .pm peacefully whilst I held him in my arms whispering prayers and love into his ears along with his brother and sister surrounded by his beautul friends.  The doctor had been on the frontline of the Covid battle since its outbreak in , and September  was just another day saving lives. Dr Halim was treated in Swindon Hospital ICU for two weeks before being transferred to The Royal Brompton in London to receive treatment on a special articial lung . He fought hard to be with his children, the youngest of whom is five, every day. A colleague said: Being a fighter, he never gave up. He kept believing he would recover. He didnapost smoke or drink, a friend said, and was someone who just helped people all the time. In a heartbreaking post on social media, Mrs Halim said: Irfan you gave me  magical years as your we, four beautul children, wonderful memories that will last me until my remaining days in this world.You gave  dedicated years service to the NHS working as a Consultant General Surgeon.Please remember him in your prayers and duas and mountains of strength for his children for the pain of losing a wonderful, beloved father at such a tender age.Irfan you were not only my best friend but a best friend to all our children and so many others. There has been an outpouring of grief among the medical community for the highly esteemed and widely respected surgeon, who worked for the NHS for  years.With a speciality in laparoscopic surgery, he also carried out work at his private clinics and at Harley Street. He held one of the highest volume practices in the UK, seeing approximately  new patients every month and personally performing over , procedures annually. Hash Syed, a colleague who worked with Dr Halim earlier in the year building a new digital health , paid tribute to his friend and said: I will cherish the fun we had building Entero at the Antler hub near Liverpool Street. Whether it be you riding around on your scooter, or our favourite burger bar. You were the definition of service to others, and believing in more. A man of many talents across being a doctor, a pilot and a lawyer. Most importantly, loving father and husband and great friend. A GoFundMe page has been set up for Dr Halimaposs family and has already raised more than £,.Mrs Halim added: He was the embodiment of ethics, unconditional friendship, a renaissance man of many skills, a scholar that has taught thousands.He was  men in one body. story: Girl, , out of school for  years as council cant find suitable placementLayla Fielding has not been in school properly for  years, her mother has claimed, but the council say the help theyve offered has not been deemed to be suitableLisa Riley with her daughter Layla Fielding , who she claims has been left without a school place for three years Image: STEVE ALLENByJosie Le VayKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov A mum claims her -year-old daughter hasnapost been in school full-time for three years as the council havenapost accommodated her needs. Lisa Riley SAYS her child Layla Fielding has been left without a proper education since year three when she was expelled. But the Bury council has refuted these claims, saying Layla has always had a school place but her mother has deemed it to be unsuitable.Layla, from Bury, has special educational needs, with Lisa telling the Manchester Evening News she has ADHD, sensory processing disorder and anxiety.In the past when she has felt overwhelmed, Layla has run out of the classroom - even managing to escape school premises altogether. It has been three years since Layla has had any regular classroom time, with Lisa giving up work to stay at home with her daughter - who has been struggling with loneliness.  I think Iaposve missed out on a lot by not going to school. Iaposve been missing out on learning, socialising and everything like that, Layla told the MEN. The lack of classroom time has had a devastating effect on her and her family, and Lisa has hit out at Bury Council for failing to find her a suitable spot. Weaposre at a stage where I feel like Iaposve got to shout out to get heard for my little girl, Lisa Riley said. Layla has told her mum: I feel like I havenapost got any friends now and I feel lonely sometimes. Layla did attend St.Joseph  St.Bedeaposs for a few weeks in the January after she was excluded from a school in Rochdale. But her mother says her flight or fight response was triggered - and she once again managed to escape the school grounds. Lisa added: It was the same scenario, Layla couldnapost cope.  Layla now sees an alternative education provider, but this is only for three two hours sessions a week, and Lisa said it is aposno substitute for the formal education her daughter deservesapos. She fears that Layla, who she says is bright and intelligent, is years behind in her learning - especially as she should be set to start secondary school in September. With the right support in place, and with staff made aware of Laylaaposs sensory issues, Lisa believes sheaposd be more than capable of having a formal education in a normal school. She said: Almost three years in, we need a suitable place for Layla to attend. And itaposs not just the academic le and learning, itaposs the social, the emotional, making friends, feeling part of a group and community that Layla is missing out on and has missed out on. And really I just find it staggering to think the council canapost accommodate or find one single place to suit Layla. My daughter deserves better than the council are delivering for her. Bury Council told the MEN Layla has had a school place for the past three years - although it had been deemed unsuitable by her mother. A spokesperson said: We always strive to ensure that all children, whatever their circumstances, are provided with the education that is most appropriate for them and in the right setting. “We have worked extensively with Ms Riley over many months to find the solution that is best for her and her daughter. At all times Layla has had a school place. “Following her exclusion, a place for Layla was provided at a primary school in Bury in . To support her successful reintegration into school a plan was agreed with a part-time in school and with specialist part-time provision off-site, however as this broke down the school moved to providing full-time offsite provision. “In January , the council agreed to fund full-time provision with an approved alternative provider to continue to work with Layla and reintegrate her back into her school environment. Her mainstream school found it challenging to meet Laylaaposs needs, but Ms Riley was of the view that a school had to be a mainstream school and special provision would not be considered. Unfortunately, this has delayed reaching an alternative arrangement for Layla. “Layla has a place at her primary school and is currently being provided with education offsite with an approved alternative provider as Layla has struggled to adapt to her school environment. “We are consulting with a range of primary mainstream schools and considering specialist provision alongside these options in order to identy the most suitable setting for Layla.” Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON EducationSchoolsSecondary schoolADHD" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: i turned every notification phone
story: I turned off every notication on my phone when I realised I was addictedFor the last six months Ive not had a single WhatsApp, email or tweet notication - my le is so much better for it, and my friends know Ill get back to them when I want, writes Lauren DudleyLauren doesnt even reply to her friends messages until shes ready - and says shes never felt better Image: Lauren DudleyopinionByLauren Dudley:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSix months ago, my minute-by-minute habit was reaching out for a buzzing phone. Late-night emails, client WhatsApps, the news, a Twitter notication, FitBit… it didn’t matter what it was. What mattered is that I was immediately available or I’d miss something transformative, I was sure of it. I’d sit at dinner, discussing a friend’s hilariously bad date, missing cues to laugh as I was too busy urging myself not to glance down at my lit up screen. I’d sit at my desk, unable to focus, being pulled out of concentration by the incessant glow. I had reached such a heightened level of contact with the outside world that I didn’t even notice how badly I needed to disconnect. One day, after a long, hard think about this habit, I did something I never thought would actually stick: I turned every single notication off.You’d think I’d be the last person on earth to actually manage this, or I certainly did anyway. I had founded amarketing agencyin the year prior. I had clients, a small team, umpteen social media accounts to manage, inquiring journalists, potential business popping up and I really believed this demanded me to be non-negotiably on, all the time. Would you ever go cold turkey on your phone notications  Have your say in the comments below Fast forward six months, I now find it incredibly odd to imagine my phone holding that much power over me. I’ve turned off every single notication, I don’t open the email app out-of-hours, and I’ve turned off the banner and badge alerts for most apps too. Nothing, except urgent phone calls, has lit up my phone for over half a year. The first two weeks were uncomfortably dficult. When you get a notication, it triggers a dopamine rush, and my own brain was addicted to this “reward”, craving the habit-based behaviour. I felt anxious for a while, semi-desperately telling everyone about it, making sure they knew to call they needed me.After that  Peace. There’s been a million ways this has benefited me in every aspect of my le but perhaps most importantly, I am able to be present, no matter where I am. Whether it’s getting my head down to plan a brand launch strategy or at the dinner table discussing future travel plans. Either way, I am finally living in the moment. People rarely call, and this always surprises me. Both my colleagues and I have realised that we believe everything is urgent, until we’re forced to decideit’s worth interrupting someone... and it often turns out, it’s just not. Clients follow the same logic. I’m a big fan of that. I can’t think of one single moment or opportunity I have missed because of this. Everyone, both professionally and personally, has better boundaries with me now. Our clients rarely WhatsApp, butand when they do, I still won’t reply out of working hours, unless itaposs an emergency - which is almost never. My friends know I’ll reply when I can , but they also know when I’m with them, I’m now both physically and mentally present. As a society, we have a painful and damaging relationship with technology, and an ever-growing notion that with all this wonderful tech, we should be far more connected than ever before. It’s undeniable that we’re privileged to have this access. But at the same time, being instantly available to everyone and anything is simply not healthy.My current wellbeing is testament to that. I used to feel anxious and overwhelmed, and while this might not be the only change I made to lessen that, it’s certainly one of the biggest. It’s liberating. I’ve learnt that you don’t ever need to apologise for being unavailable. You don’t need to give anyone that instant access to you. You don’t need to be actively busy to not respond - you’re entitled to be actively not-busy and still unavailable. Those boundaries are healthy and should become society’s norm. And I truly believe,you challenge yourself to three weeks, this will become your norm too. Christian convert Emad Al Swealmeen, , spent months building up a supply of dangerous chemicals at a rented flat in the city, where he is believed to have attempted to make multiple explosives. He was the only person killed as his bomb detonated in a taxi outside Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital on Sunday morning. Counter-terrorism sources told The Times that he attempted to construct a device using primary and secondary explosives to magny the blast. Similar bombs were used during the  attack on the London tube, when four al-Qaeda inspired terrorists killed  innocent people in simultaneous attacks in the capital. Yesterday streets around Al Swealmeenaposs flat were cordoned off after a package was discovered, with bomb disposal officers called to the scene. story: Man sees things in cartoon vision after multiple strokes cause rare conditionGraham Varley, , suffers from a rare condition called Charles Bonnet Syndrome which means he still does not know what his -year-old granddaughter looks likeA Leeds man has spoken out about the reality of living with a rare condition that hugely affects his vision Image: MEN MEDIAByJasmine NordenKieren Williams:,  Nov | commentsA British man now “sees things in cartoon vision” after suffering from multiple strokes. Graham Varley, from Leeds, had multiple strokes in  that severely affected his sight, and caused a rare condition called Charles Bonnet Syndrome. This means the -year-old will see things that aren’t there, as well as often not being able to recognise other people’s faces, LeedsLive reports. Graham said: What happened to me is so rare, and so strange and it really has been horrible to deal with. I wouldn’t wish it on anyone. But four years on – I feel like I’ve started to live again. He was a bakery manager at the time, and thought he was just having a normal headache in  as he worked. But he collapsed and was rushed to hospital where it had been revealed that the blood had been cut off from the main artery to his brain.  This left him with right-sided hemianopia, the loss of half your visual field. Graham said: “After my strokes I not only had to learn to do everything again like read and write, and even learn how to get dressed, but I also lost the majority of my vision – and on Christmas Day of all days. The only sight I have left is a bit in the top right of my eyes – I cannot focus and have no perception of D, so everything I can see looks like a cartoon. “One of the most disturbing things caused by my sight loss, is Charles Bonnet Syndrome, which causes me to see things that aren’t there. Sometimes it can be things looking a dferent colour than they are, such as grass being pink or a tree being purple, but other times it can cause me to have hallucinations that can be quite frightening – such as a car coming towards me, or quite often, huge spiderwebs.”  He also suffers from something called prosopagnosia, which is when he cannot recognise people’s faces. Because of this he still does not know what his two-year-old granddaughter looks like as his condition means she looks dferent to him each time. He added: “My doctor tells me I still have two blood clots on the brain that are dormant but they can move about and that causes my sight to change all the time, because signals aren’t going to the correct place. “So some days I look at Grfin, my guide dog, and with the partial vision I have, he looks like a cartoon dog.” After leaving hospital, Graham went a year waiting for support, relying on friends and carers. He was assigned to several specialists and in November last year partnered with a guide dog Grfin.  Funnily enough I wasn’t keen on a black Labrador, but then when Grfin came on to the scene, within  hours I was smitten! Graham said. “I have had dogs all my le, but I’ve never put my trust in one as I do now. We go out every day together – he’s opened up my le so much. The furthest I used to go was to the end of my driveway and back, but now we walk three or four miles a day.“With my Charles Bonnet Syndrome, Grfin helps me know what is real and what isn’t. If I see something ahead of me but Grfin keeps on walking, I know that it’s a hallucination. “Yesterday, with Grfin by my side, was the first time I’ve been in the supermarket by myself in four years. A few weeks ago, it was the first time since my stroke that I’ve been to the barbers. I feel like I’ve got my confidence back – I didn’t do any of the things that I do now, without Grfin. “I’ve even taken him to the pub and everyone’s got to know him - he goes to say hello to everyone and now he’s a local celebrity! I’ve never trusted anyone like I do Grfin - he is truly amazing and I’m so grateful to Guide Dogs and the team for their support.” Graham lives with we Mandy, and is also supported by a carer. news uk-news prince-charles-urges-young-people-"Prince Charles visits the Al Azhar Mosque in CairoByRussell MyersRoyal editor:,  Nov | commentsThe Prince of Wales has urged young people studying in an Egyptian mosque to remember all we have in common, not what ides us. The Prince, visiting the Al Alzar mosque in Cairo, told students the most important thing is to focus on the shared beliefs across faiths. We share so much, he said. The Prince and Duchess of Cornwall visited the Al Azhar Mosque shortly after landing in Cairo this morning, viewing the spectacular architecture and posing for a photograph in the central courtyard. They met the Grand Imam Sheikh Ahmed El-Tayeb, accompanied by the Archbishop of the Anglican Province of Alexandria, Dr Samy Fawzy.  After the Duchess departed to begin her own programme in Cairo, the Prince attended an interfaith reception in closed Abassa room of the mosque. There, he was said to be in “deep conversation” with the Grand Imam, surrounded by their entourages. The leaders were later joined by six Al-Azhar scholars, who told the Prince about their studies in English, religion and climate change.  The British Council has been running an Al-Azhar UK Academic Scholarship scheme since . It aims to promote mutual understanding among a new generation of Muslim and non-Muslim scholars, and allows students to study for degrees in Islamic studies at British universities before ing to Al-Azhar University to work as faculty members. As patron of the scheme, the Prince hosted six students from the programme at Clarence House in March , with two of them - Mariam Shehata and Muhammed Al-Marakby - joining him again today.  He asked them about their studies, and whether they had noticed a “growing awareness” from people about the importance of talking about climate change. The Prince went on to meet groups of students learning English at the mosque, with young men and women arranged in small groups to speak to him. The most important thing is to emphasise what we have in common not what ides us,” the Prince told one group of women. “Do remember that. We share so much.  He asked them of their studies: Have you managed through the worst of the pandemic  Did you do it all online  Stopping to talk to a second group, he wondered: “Are you actually able to sit down with representatives from other faiths for conversation  Learning a bit from each other  There must be a lot of people your age who want to do this sort of course with the British Council.  Of learning languages, he added: Its practising isnapost it  Thats whataposs so dficult. My Arabic needs practice. Founded in AD , the mosque is one of Cairo’s earliest and considered an architectural wonder. Its university is the second-oldest educational institution in the world, and is a centre of Islamic learning.  The royal couple last visited Al-Azhar in , when the Prince of Wales received an honorary doctorate from Al-Azhar University, which is considered the foremost Islamic institution in the Sunni Muslim world. title: queen buys every staff member
story: Queen buys every staff member a £ present from Tesco for Christmas each yearEvery year, the , staff members are reportedly given the same festive gt - although the annual ceremony was cancelled last year, due to coronavirus restrictionsThe much-loved tradition allows the monarch to thank her staff personally Image: PAByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsThe Queen could bring back a much-loved tradition this year - by gting her , members of staff the same present.Each year, the annual ceremony hits the headlines - after the tradition was reportedly started by Her Majestyaposs grandfather George V.It sees the -year-old monarch present each member of her workforce with a Christmas pudding - though the ceremony was cancelled last year due to the pandemic. The Royal Family website confirms this, stating: All members of The Royal Household will receive Christmas presents from The Queen, and Her Majesty will personally hand out presents to some members of The Royal Household at Buckingham Palace and at Windsor Castle.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. Continuing the tradition from her father, King George VI and her grandfather, George V – The Queen also gives Christmas puddings to her staff. About  Christmas puddings paid for by The Queenare distributed to staff throughout the Palaces, staff in the Court Post Office and Palace police. Each pudding is accompanied by a greeting card. Historically, Palace staff have received a luxury pud from brands such as Harrods or royal grocer Fortnum  Mason.  But Hello magazine reports the Queen now opts for a £ Tesco version instead - which saves a lot of cash. Last year, the Queen was forced to axe her annual Christmas gt-giving ceremony for staff for the first time in her reign. The Monarch traditionally purchases a small gt for every member of the royal staff, which she personally presents alongside the Christmas pud, to thank the workers. In the past, employees have been treated to photo frames and champagne flutes. The Queen will be spending her first Christmas without her husband Prince Philipaposs following his death earlier this year in April this year, aged .She has faced a number of health concerns in recent weeks, after being hospitalised for a night in October and then having to cancel her appearance at the Remembrance Day service in Westminster after spraining her back. title: royal navy race against russians
story: Royal Navy in race against Russians to recover crashed F- jet from sea floorBritish Armed Forces were scrambling to recover pieces of the destroyed F- warplane, which has top secret technology, from the Mediterranean in case it falls into enemy handsAn F-B with sensitive technology crashed in the MediterraneanImage: Lockheed MartinByChris HughesDefence and Security EditorTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsThe Royal Navy was in a race against the Russians to recover a £ million UK warplane with top secret technology after it crashed into the Mediterranean. A British pilot dramatically ejected from the F-B Lightning on a routine exercise that is believed to have smashed up on impact in the sea but pieces of the destroyed aircraft would still contain highly sensitive features. The pilot was part of the UK’s HMS Queen Elizabeth aircraft carrier strike force, which was practising for war. Technology on the aircraft includes top secret radar and sensors that allows the F-B to fly at supersonic speeds without being seen. It is unknown whether an F-B has crashed before in international waters but at the same time it is probable that China is aware of the secret technology through spying.  It is the RAFaposs most advanced plane capable of landing vertically and is the first that the UK has lost. British Armed Forces were last night scrambling to recover pieces of the destroyed warplane in case it falls into enemy hands, such as the Russian navy.The wreckage of the plane was found on Wednesday afternoon and is being protected by an Anglo-US e team until the aircraft is able to be removed by the Navy, reported the Daily Mail. It is believed the pilot is recovering and back on the ship following the crash which happened at am on Wednesday. He was rescued after an emergency operation was launched. An MoD spokesperson said: “A British F pilot from HMS Queen Elizabeth ejected during routine flying operations in the Mediterranean this morning.  “The pilot has been safely ed to the ship and an investigation has begun, so it would be inappropriate to comment further at this time.” The Mirror understands no other vessels were involved in the incident and the MoD has ordered a probe into what went wrong. There are approximately  F-B jets on the Queen Elizabeth, a £. billion aircraft carrier which is the UK’s biggest-ever warship. The carrier’s F-Bs are equally ided on the ship between the UK’s Royal Air Force and the US Marine Corps. The Queen Elizabeth has a sister carrier called HMS Prince of Wales which is undergoing sea trials.  Sources told the Daily Mirror he was rescued by “assets launching from HMS Queen Elizabeth” which means he was likely plucked from the sea by a Merlin helicopter. It is believed he has had a medical checkup but is not in the ship’s hospital. The Mirror understands the plane was destroyed after it piled at speed into the water shortly after the flyer ejected. At the time of the crash HMS Queen Elizabeth was in the Eastern Mediterranean, on the way back to the UK from the China Sea. It is not known how far the plane was from its mother ship when it ran into trouble. This is the first major mission for the carrier, which is accompanied by a number of other Royal Navy warships. There were eight UK F-Bs on board HMS Elizabeth before the crash and ten US Marine Corps F-Bs. Sources said it was “early days” in the investigation and the devastating smash remains a mystery. One told the Mirror: “It could have been a seagull strike, at the moment we don’t know. “But the most important thing is that the pilot has survived. “It is not yet knownthere was a fault in the plane.” Another source told the Mirror other FB flights in the UK from RAF Marham are not being suspended. title: tiny london flat bunk bed
story: Tiny London flat with bunk bed next to kitchen and no bathroom door costs £ a monthThe property in Barons Court, West London, has a bunk bed just next to the kitchen, with no space to walk around. It costs £ per month and is available for a long letThe flat costs £ a month to rent despite only having a bunk bed right next to the kitchen Image: Right MoveByBeth GulliverChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov | commentsA small studio flat which has a bunk bed right next to the kitchen and a bathroom without a door can be rented for £ a month.The property in Barons Court, west London, is described on the property website Rightmove as a good size studio despite being only  square feet.It features an area with a bunk bed just next to the kitchen, with no space to walk around.Pictures on the property site also show a shower within the studio with a curtain, but no door separating it from the rest of the living area, My London reports.What do you think of this rental  Let us know in the comments below It is not clear where the toilet is as it cannot be seen from the images posted on the listing.The .m x .m flat is on Castletown Road, not far from Fulham, and is set on the third floor of a brick building. It is close to West Kensington and Barons Court underground stations for an easy commute. There are local amenities too, including a Michelin-starred pub called The Harwood Arms and plenty of shops.  It costs £ per month, is available for a long let, and can be rented with zero deposit. Estate agents Foxtons described the flat as a good-sized living space that is presented in a neutral décor. Foxtons added the flat has bright and airy interiors and an open plan kitchen with built-in storage.Last month, a property smaller than the size of an average parking space went on sale for £,.The studio in Notting Hill, west London, is just  square feetand contains a bed, sink, toilet and shower - but no kitchen. In comparison, the typical size of a parking space in the UK is  square feet.The property cannot be occupied as a permanent residence or let out, the sellers have stated, and only cash purchases will be accepted.According to the property website Zoopla, the flat offers a wonderful opportunity to create a London bolt hole in this prime central location. title: toddler been 28 holidays mum
story: Toddler has been on  holidays with mum and dad despite being just  months oldFteen-month-old Jude has been racking up countries including Italy, Switzerland and even Australia since he was two months old and even took his first steps on a beach in Valencia, SpainThis tot has spent most of his le travelling around Europe in a stylish camper van Image: littlefeetbigwheels   MERCURY PRESSByLucy Notarantonio:,  Nov | comments Most of us don’t get to half of these places in a letime but this tot traveller has notched up  destinations in his  months.Fteen-month-old Jude has been racking up countries with parents Sarah Cansfield and Lochie Kerr since he was two months old.He took his first steps on a beach in Valencia and has now visited  dferent places in six countries, plus the UK, reports the Daily Record. From Croatia and France to Italy, Spain, Switzerland and even Australia, Jude has an enviable photo album.His parents, who work in finance, moved out of their London flat in October  and into a Citroen Relay LH van. Do you have a story that you think we should feature  Get in touch with us at webnews@mirrorAberdonian Sarah, , said: “Travelling and living in a van is all Jude has ever known. “He adapts very well to new surroundings and loves meeting new people. It has been brilliant as we have everything we need. “We aren’t living out of a case or waiting on planes that may be delayed. “Driving is easier as we can stop for a swim or naphe needs one. He loves sand and sea.”  The trio set off in October  and ed back to Tottenham, London, in September this year in their £, van.But while young Jude has already experienced more countries than some adults, recent research found that two-thirds of children think holidays in the UK are just as - or more - fun as going abroad.A survey of , boys and girls aged six to  revealed three-quartersthink it is important to see as many of the best UK sights as possible before heading somewhere .  The ideal experience for a child is a visit to a waterpark, followed by a day at the beach - with an adventure at a theme park taking third spot. Making up the top five are the opportunity to swim in the sea, and being able to go and eat your favourite kind of food. The research was carried out by Premier Inn as families across the country prepare to go away for a half term holiday. TikTok star Luisana, @luisanaugel, set up the camera which saw her pug sitting patiently by the door, waiting for her to .The owner even left food to distract him, but the moment he finished it, he just sat dutully waiting for his masteraposs . TeamDogs is a community for dog lovers who want to get the most out of their relationship with their best pal. Make sharing the cutest photos of your dog your first job on the website and after youaposve done that, leave a tip to help fellow dog owners live their best lives as a proud pooch parent. Search through hundreds of recommended walks, treats, toys and places to stay when youaposre on an adventure together. From dog-friendly pubs to product reviews and the latest news, you can snf it all out at TeamDogs.A vets left the internet sobbing after sharing the heartbreaking reason why they keep a jar ofchocolates labelled ‘goodbye kisses’at the surgery.Smiths Station Animal Hospital in Alabama, US, has a jar full of chocolates to give to dogs who are about to be euthanised because no dog should go to heaven without tasting chocolate.The practice posted a photo of their ‘goodbye kisses’ jar, specially reserved for dogs about to pass over the rainbow bridge.Jenner Williams, manager of the hospital, told Fox News that technician Casey Hinkley came up with the idea for the facility after seeing a similar jar online. Tracy Gee made the jar and Dr. Nicole Namie came up with the quote, which was shared on the hospital’s Facebook page.Heartbroken pet owners flocked to the comments section and flooded it with tributes to their pets along with what treats they fed to them on their last day. Just to be a part of the grieving process is really special.” One viewer said they were ‘crying in under seven seconds’ after Megan showed a photo of a German shepherd holding the toy she’d just painted his portrait onto. ‘How do I use this ’  Susie had never lived in a house before she arrived at her foster home in Canada - and so everything was a completely new experience for her.While most dogs would jump at the opportunity to curl up on a cosy sofa pillow, a TikTok video saw a confusedSusie unable to work out how to use a cushion- as she’d never seen one before.In the clip, captioned: “Foster pups often don’t know how to ‘dog’ when they arrive. The Tiktoker, from Canada, said it took the pup half an hour to walk  metres because she was so unsure of the world. But it would make me very happy to know that some younger doggies would have fun with them. Love from Jarvis.” The sweet gesture was thought up by Jarvis the cocker spaniel’s owner, Lian Wymer.She said: “Jarvis is nearly  now and he’s got very severe arthritis, so he’s no longer fit for ball games. So I put them in a box, wrote a little note on it and left it in the park.” Last ice cream for Marley Viewers were left sobbing after eight-year-old boxer cross Marley took hislast ever trip to the ice cream van.After discovering the dog had a fast-growing cancerous tumour in his mouth, his owner Katie Dixon wanted to hear him sing to the tune of his favourite ice cream van one last time. story: Universal Credit loan: Emergency £, loan could be yours in time for ChristmasChristmas is on the way, bringing with it financial uncertainties of how to get through the season. But respite could be available for those who qualy for an interest free loanA little known scheme for Universal Credit claimants could ease some money worries, with interest free loans of up to £, Image: PAByTom HaynesKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsChristmas is fast approaching, bringing with it a raft of money worries for many families about how they will cope financially with the festive season.But a little known scheme for Universal Credit claimants could ease some money worries, with interest free loans of up to £, for those who are waiting for their first payment to come through. The loan can also be accessed by those who need more money due to a sudden change in circumstances, like having a baby, MyLondon reports. Universal Credit claimants are facing a tougher time than ever after the temporary uplt given during lockdown was snatched away in October, just as increases in energy and food costs starting biting at peopleaposs pockets.  Those making a claim for Universal Credit face a five-week wait for the money, which can leave some struggling for cash to pay bills. The advance payment is currently being offered via the Department for Work and Pensions , which will allow claimants to borrow money then pay it back in installments. The loans are interest free - and the amount claimants can get depends on how much Universal Credit they are entitled to. The maximum amount claimants can borrow is currently £,. Claimants can as for up to  per cent of the amount but can also ask for less.  Borrowed money should be with claimants within three days of making a claim and will have to make the money last five weeks until the UC payment comes through. The money deducted from your next UC payment can be worked out by iding the full cost by Claimants who get a job and stop claiming UC will still have to repay the loan. Those wishing to make a claim should apply through JobCentre   . Applications made because of a change in circumstance should be done over the phone. Applicants will need to explain their reasons for needing the loan - and wonapost get the payment automatically. They will also need to be able to prove that they can pay back the cash, and agree a rate at which the loan will be repaid. Those struggling to repay an advance will be able to pause a repayment for up to three months . Applicants are advised to contact their work coach or ask online for further assistance. story: What its REALLY like working at McDonalds Drive-Thru - panic alarm to secret camerasIve caught staff crying in the freezer and behind the bins during the obligatory mid-sht breakdown - spare a thought for us the next time you order your p cheeseburger, writes McDonalds Drive-Thru worker Dom Lee*We can see and hear everything you do while youre waiting to give your order at the speakers Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDom Lee:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThere’s nothing more rewarding than a towering Big Mac accompanied by salty , hotfries from a McDonald’s Drive-Thru on a Friday night. But while this treat might feel like heaven, believe me, itaposs Hell working there. Whether it’s the medley of teenage lads shouting “Here comes Fatty” to me as they scoff a p cheeseburger, or the experience of witnessing a grown man rip off a Covid- protection window due to a lack of milkshakes, my six years at McDonalds have been nothing short of a flurry. After applying fresh out of high school , McDonald’s flexible hours and healthy rate of pay was extremely attractive to a skint first-year college student. And while most worry the lack of experience would be the issue with younger staff members, it’s the drama you’ve got to watch out for.  Once you’re past the three-month probation - during which most existing staff members refuse to acknowledge your existence - every fresh cohort brings a brand-new tier to Macciesapos ever growing political chain. However, the real initiation isn’t complete without the obligatory mid-sht breakdown. I can’t tell you how many people I’ve caught crying in the freezer, the stock room, even behind the bins. It’s a rite of passage for new staff members. Keeping a brave face is at least  percent of the job. From the Friday stampede of orders , to shovelling the remnants of half-chewed chicken nuggets from abandoned trays into the bin, and even having abuse hurledfor receiving cold food “after waiting for half an hour” always half an hour.It’s all just a part of the job.  That’s not to say every customer is rude, though. But there are the ones who test patience in a busy Drive-Thru. Firstly, nothing is LESS funny than when people try and order a Wicked Zinger Box Meal. Secondly, on behalf of every McDonald’s worker, we don’t serve mayonnaise. I don’t know why we don’t serve mayonnaise I don’t know IF we will ever serve mayonnaise and “speaking to the manager” about the lack of mayonnaise certainly isn’t going to solve anything. Thirdly, we can hear and see everything you do while you’re waiting to give your order by the Drive-Thru speakers. I can’t tell you how many solo renditions of cringe ‘s pop hits I’ve heard over the years. Alas, the serenade of freshly driving teens and those who queue for half an hour for the sake of a bottle of waterblocks out the eight hours of incessant beeping machines. *The writeraposs name has been changed. story: Woman given a % chance of conceiving baby falls pregnant after losing  stoneElla Marsh, , from Havant, Hampshire, fell pregnant after dropping from a size  to a  with the help of a gastric sleeve, having been trying for six yearsElla Marsh, , fell pregnant in June after dropping from a size  to a  Image: Mercury Press  Media Ltd.ByBeth Ure:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman who was given a one per cent chance of naturally conceiving a baby has fallen pregnant after losing eight stone.Ella Marsh, , was trying to get pregnant for six years with her husband Dylan, . Her doctor recommended losing weight to increase her chances of conceiving, but still felt there was almost no chance of it happening.The customer service advisor, who lives in Havant, Hampshire, finally fell pregnant in June after dropping from a size  to a . She said: Iaposve always wanted to be a mum, ever since I was a little girl. It was so hard trying for so many years, every negative test was more upsetting. I used to comfort eat to try and cheer myself up.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Eventually, in August , I decided enough was enough and had a gastric sleeve as I couldnapost lose the weight on my own. Just under a year later and two weeks after an IVF consultation, I fell pregnant naturally. I did about  tests because I just couldnapost believe it. Ella used her savings and had help from family to fund the £ surgery.Now, halfway through her pregnancy, Ella is feeling better than ever.She said: We are so over the moon, she is a little miracle. Before my weight loss I was very shy and insecure. Now, Iaposm so confident, I go out with my friends more and I love shopping. Ella explained her initial weight gain stemmed from her childhood. She said: I would turn to food for comfort, which progressed as I got older. When we first started trying, I was getting more depressed as the days went on, and worrying that I would never get pregnant. Those feelings led me to eat more, and I was stuck in this cycle. Ella used to eat three or more takeaways per week which would often include additional sides.  She said: I had tried diets for years, but nothing was working. I tried to be strict with myself, and only have a shake for a meal, but I still wasnapost losing weight. The only option was surgery. I used it as a tool to stop my bad eating habits and to finally lose weight once and for all. After the surgery, Ella was given the shocking news that she wasnapost ovulating. She said: I was devastated, I thought I would never be a mum. We were referred to an IVF clinic and had a consultation there. Two weeks after that I found out I was pregnant! Battling infertility is so hard, but itaposs important you donapost lose hope. The best thing Iaposve ever done in my le is going and speaking to my doctor about it. Thataposs how we got here, because they first recommended losing weight to help us conceive. I never in a million years thought it would ever happen naturally considering the odds were completely against us. Now, Iaposm pregnant with my dream baby. story: Woman who begged council to fix roof for SIX YEARS devastated as ceiling caves inYvonne Cochrane, , has lived in a flat in Glenburn Crescent, Paisley, Renfrewshire, for  years. She said last month the ceiling collapsed and landed on her bedThe ceiling collapsed last month Image: Andrew NeilByAlison RennieChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman said she begged her local council to fix her propertyaposs roof for six years before it caved in earlier this month. Yvonne Cochrane, , has lived in a flat in Glenburn Crescent, Paisley, Renfrewshire, for  years.She is a Renfrewshire Council tenant along with one other resident of the four-in-a-block, the Daily Record reports.Yvonne, who has epilepsy and the lung condition COPD, said a roof tile blew off the rear of the building six years ago, but the council did not repair it as they could not agree on a price with the two private owners. However, Renfrewshire Council said it responded to all the roof repairs reported by the tenant and completed work to fix them.  Do you have a story you think we should cover  Get in touch at webnews@mirror Yvonne said that as years passed the damage worsened, causing the ceiling to collapse and land on her bed. Due to the issue, water has also been getting into the building, the woman said. Yvonne said the propertyaposs issue has been causing problems for her health, as she explained: The water is all coming in from the gutter, it’s never been cleared. There are big cracks right down the building.  The roof tile came off six years ago above the back bedroom. I was told I couldn’t get a replacement because the neighbours wouldn’t pay for it. The walls are wet and it’s not good for my health, my breathing is affected. The ceiling came right down and landed on my bed. Yvonne phoned Renfrewshire Council on October  when the ceiling caved in. She claimed she was told an inspector would visit the property on November .  The resident explained: They said that’s the first appointment they’ve got. If theyaposd replaced the missing tile six years ago this wouldn’t have happened. I’ve just had enough of this. title: horror images show mangled car
story: Horror images show mangled car folded in two under -wheeler truck but woman SURVIVEDA -year-old woman from survived a horror crash that saw an -wheeler truck smash into her car and fold it in two - astonishing pictures show how lucky she was to escape with her leA -year-old woman sustained only minor injuries after her car was crushed and folded in two Image: @wspdpio TwitterByKieren Williams:,  Nov | commentsA woman survived a horror crash with only minor injuries after an -wheeler truck ran over her car and crushed it. The -year-old woman was reportedly inside her car when the truck failed to stop behind her yesterday. The truck slammed into the Nissan and pushed it into another truck, which caused it to fold in two and the -wheeler to crash over the top of it. Washington State Trooper Rocky Oliphant tweeted saying: “In my  year career, I have never seen anything like it. Thereaposs really not a word to describe this collision.” The horric pictures show the sheer extent of the damage to the vehicle that somehow the driver survived, mostly unscathed.  The huge truck sits squat on top of the red car which has been crushed in the crash in Washington, US. Such was the impact and size of the truck that they had to use a tow truck to lt its front end up and allow the woman could escape. Once it was lted up, she crawled out herself.When speaking to Fox  Oliphant described how the impact on the small car was so big that it ‘folded the back end of the car over onto the rear compartment.” He said: When troopers arrived, we could still hear a person inside the car. That person was able to get out of the car and walk out by themselves. It is beyond words to describe how somebody was able to walk away from that car. When they were trying to free the woman front he car, the traffic was causing the bridge to move, making the tow truck unstable. Both lanes had to be closed until the woman was freed.  Speaking to Seattle Times, he described the woman surviving the crash as a “perfect storm”.He described how because the back end of the woman’s car folded up and over, facing the front, it kept some of the truck’s weight off the passenger compartment and created a ramp for the truck to drive up and over. He said: “Lucky is not the right word because that was not a lucky collision. His landlord sued him, alleging he damaged the propertyThe flat in Hudson Street, New York City, was transformed into a night club, court papers sayByChiara Fiorillo:,  Nov A landlord is suing his former tenant for over £, after he allegedly turned his flat into a night club during the pandemic, hosting rowdy house parties. Kurt David, , lived in the two-storey property in Tribeca, New York City, but moved out in June, according to reports. His landlord, identied as Eisdorfer  LLC in a lawsuit, alleged the tenant held parties at the house, inviting hundreds of people who had to pay for entry. The property, which cost ,a month, was turned into a night club where party-goers drank alcohol and smoke marijuana, court papers say. The parties, held during the coronavirus pandemic, were in breach of restrictions and the host was arrested twice for them, according to US media. On March , officers broke up a party with more than  people who were not wearing face masks, Gothamist reports.A -year-old, who was apparently drunk, had to be taken to a local hospital after falling from the stairs, Sherf Joseph Fucito said. The teenager later told investigators he had bought alcohol at the party. David was arrested and charged with selling alcohol to minors, unlawfully dealing with children, and violating emergency orders. He was fined ,for failure to protect health and safety, according to reports.  The previous month, the tenant had been charged with misdemeanours after officers broke up another party. Court documents say: The scene Defendants have created appears to be that of a nightclub, causing the severe disturbance to last into the early hours of the morning. These parties attract such a high-volume crowd that the Defendants have hired security guards bouncers to operate the door when letting guests into the Premises. Now, the landlord is suing David and his mother Jean Elbaum-David, who also signed the lease, for four months of unpaid rent, late fees, violations charges from the Department of Buildings and Sanitation, legal fees and for the cost of fixing the house.  The lawsuit alleges the company had to pay ,to fix the property, including replacing broken appliances, window shades, balcony and roof pavers, faucets, the sound system, the security and camera system, the intercom, window panes, drywall, hardwood floors and a bathroom vanity unit, the New York Post reports.The company also said they had to paint the property, fix the electrical system and employ heavy-duty cleaners to make the flat livable again. David told the New York Post he was a legal resident of the building and that he had paid rent. He said: Rent has been paid on time over the duration of the full-year lease and due to Covid-, I filed the Covid- hardship declaration and the landlord holds ,for two months security and one-week free rent. story: Cafe ides opinion after publicly shaming a mum for leaving a mess behindCorbys Tea Room vented their frustration on social media after the woman and her -month old toddler had left, saying they didnt help tidy up or offer an apologyPaul Crush, the owner of Corbys Tea Room in Ramsgate, has since apologised Image: GoogleByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov | commentsOne cafe ided opinion after publicly shaming a mother for leaving a mess behind. Corbyaposs Tea Room uploaded photographs of the table where the mum had been sitting, showing food scattered across the floor and around a high chair.But the womanaposs sister, who saw the post on Facebook, branded the cafeaposs behaviour as disgusting.The post reads: Whilst we welcome mums and toddlers, what we don’t welcome is a mess left like this with no attempt to help tidy or offer of apology and then when challenged to say weakly, aposI left a tip last timeapos. She shared a screenshot of the original post captioned: Absolutely disgusting behaviour from a so-called business. Didnapost seem to have a problem until after they had paid and tipped you. Personally, I think by the fact you deleted your post you are admitting perhaps getting a dustpan and brush isnapost such a hard task. But donapost worry, even though you told my sister and her -month-old baby they were never allowed in your tearoom again, I doubt theyaposd want to after such a disgusting display of unprofessional behaviour. Her rant has since sparked a debate, with commenters weighing in on both sides. One person said: Would have taken  seconds for the mum to pick that up. Hardly rude of the staff is it. Another pointed out: That is a mess. Would you leave a friendaposs place like that  Highly doubt it. Others came to the motheraposs defence saying: That mess genuinely isnapost bad for a young child eating  Iaposm astounded theyaposd publicly shame like this. We firmly believe hospitality is there to serve all customers and yes, we understand we have to clean up after them, but a simple recognition would be nice. Mr Crush said: We are an old-fashioned, friendly tearoom – check out all the real reviews on ious s – and we welcome everyone.I would like to emphasise that since taking over Corby’s three years ago we have actively introduced more child-friendly menus and facilities, including a baby-changing station. “In what continues to be a very challenging time to own and run a small independent business, this unnecessary and unfair distraction doesnapost help. The screenshot remains on the site however, which Mr Crush says violates the Facebook pageaposs rules as businesses should no be named. He has since informed the pageaposs admin.
